description: A massive blackout corrupts Tribunal archives, forcing suspension of testimony and plunging the city into confusion over future governance.

Lenart Kova, acting on his own and aware of growing distrust, severs the last active digital feeds. The BCI is permanently disabled, and adaptive algorithms are erased. Lenart’s action is relayed via trusted contacts to grassroots leaders.

Grassroots councils swiftly take charge of local services, distributing paper ration cards and holding public assemblies. Residents abandon reliance on digital scores, turning to face-to-face decision making.
Directorate loyalists attempt to discreetly revive BCI scoring, but these efforts are exposed by local leaders, who rally neighborhoods in defense of newly-won analog autonomy.

Under mounting public and internal pressure, the fractured Council announces a citywide analog referendum. Ballots are distributed for all residents to vote, deciding between decentralized neighborhood governance or a return to central authority.

Referendum results are announced: a narrow majority chooses permanent decentralized, neighborhood-based councils. The city celebrates its new autonomy, even as uncertainty and debate about Stenograd’s future continue.
